008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.image;
010
011import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
012import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
013import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d.PntInt;
014import imagingbook.common.geometry.mappings.Mapping2D;
015import imagingbook.common.image.access.ImageAccessor;
016import imagingbook.common.image.interpolation.InterpolationMethod;
017
018/**
019 * This class defines methods to perform arbitrary geometric transformations
020 * on images. The geometric transformation (mapping) must be specified at
021 * construction.
022 * The specified geometric mapping is supposed to be INVERTED, i.e. transforming
023 * <strong>target to source</strong> coordinates!
024 * For reading pixel values (from the source image) the out-of-bounds strategy and
025 * pixel interpolation method can be specified.
026 * All methods work for both scalar-valued and color images.
027 * 
028 * @author WB
029 * @version 2021/08/27
030 * @version 2022/09/16 revised
031 * 
032 * @see ImageAccessor
033 * @see Mapping2D
034 */
035public class ImageMapper {
036        
037        /** Default out-of-bounds strategy (see {@link OutOfBoundsStrategy}). */
038        public static OutOfBoundsStrategy DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy = OutOfBoundsStrategy.NearestBorder;       
039        
040        /** Default pixel interpolation method (see {@link InterpolationMethod}). */
041        public static InterpolationMethod DefaultInterpolationMethod = InterpolationMethod.Bicubic;     
042        
043        private final OutOfBoundsStrategy obs;
044        private final InterpolationMethod ipm;
045        private final Mapping2D mapping;
046        
047        /**
048         * Constructor - creates a new {@link ImageMapper} with the specified geometric
049         * mapping. The default pixel interpolation method (see
050         * {@link #DefaultInterpolationMethod}) and out-of-bounds strategy (see
051         * {@link #DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy}) are used.
052         * 
053         * @param targetToSourceMapping the geometric (target to source) transformation
054         */
055        public ImageMapper(Mapping2D targetToSourceMapping) {
056                this(targetToSourceMapping, DefaultOutOfBoundsStrategy, DefaultInterpolationMethod);
057        }
058
059        /**
060         * Constructor - creates a new {@link ImageMapper} with the specified geometric mapping,
061         * out-of-bounds strategy and pixel interpolation method.
062         * 
063         * @param targetToSourceMapping the geometric (target to source) transformation
064         * @param obs the out-of-bounds strategy (affects source image only)
065         * @param ipm the pixel interpolation method
066         */
067        public ImageMapper(Mapping2D targetToSourceMapping, OutOfBoundsStrategy obs, InterpolationMethod ipm) {
068                this.mapping = targetToSourceMapping;
069                this.obs = obs;
070                this.ipm = ipm;
071        }
072        
073        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
074        
075        /**
076         * Destructively transforms the passed image using this geometric
077         * mapping and the specified pixel interpolation method.
078         * 
079         * @param ip target image to which this mapping is applied
080         */
081        public void map(ImageProcessor ip) {
082                // make a temporary copy of the image:
083                ImageProcessor source = ip.duplicate();
084                ImageProcessor target = ip;
085                map(source, target);
086                source = null;
087        }
088        
089        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
090        
091        /**
092         * Transforms the source image to the target image using this geometric
093         * mapping and the specified pixel interpolation method. Note that source
094         * and target must be different images!
095         * The geometric mapping is supposed to be INVERTED, i.e. transforming
096         * target to source image coordinates!
097         * 
098         * @param source input image (not modified)
099         * @param target output image (modified)
100         */
101        public void map(ImageProcessor source, ImageProcessor target) {
102                if (target == source) {
103                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("source and target image must not be the same!");
104                }
105                ImageAccessor sourceAcc = ImageAccessor.create(source, obs, ipm);
106                ImageAccessor targetAcc = ImageAccessor.create(target);
107                map(sourceAcc, targetAcc);
108        }
109
110        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
111
112        /**
113         * Transforms the source image to the target image using this geometric
114         * mapping and the specified pixel interpolation method.
115         * The two images are passed as instances of {@link ImageAccessor}.
116         * Note that source and target must be different images!
117         * The geometric mapping is supposed to be INVERTED, i.e. transforming
118         * target to source image coordinates.
119         * Access to source pixels is controlled by the out-of-bounds strategy and pixel
120         * interpolation method settings of the source {@link ImageAccessor}
121         * (the corresponding settings of this {@link ImageAccessor} are ignored).
122         * 
123         * @param sourceAcc {@link ImageAccessor} for the source image
124         * @param targetAcc {@link ImageAccessor} for the target image
125         */
126        public void map(ImageAccessor sourceAcc, ImageAccessor targetAcc) {
127                if (targetAcc.getProcessor() == sourceAcc.getProcessor()) {
128                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Source and target image must not be the same!");
129                }
130                ImageProcessor target = targetAcc.getProcessor();
131                final int w = target.getWidth();
132                final int h = target.getHeight();
133                for (int v = 0; v < h; v++) {
134                        for (int u = 0; u < w; u++) {
135                                Pnt2d sourcePt = this.mapping.applyTo(PntInt.from(u, v));
136                                float[] val = sourceAcc.getPix(sourcePt.getX(), sourcePt.getY());
137                                targetAcc.setPix(u, v, val);
138                        }
139                }
140        }
141
142}
